bboxes.raw_text:
The Message is succnct and satisfactory expo
sition of the relations between the United States and
the other nations OF the world, and of our internal
condition, both as regards our institutions and re-
sources. A considerable portion the Messageis
of necessity, devoted to the history and present
state of our various differences with Great Britain
on the subjects of boundary, intercourse and trade
In relation to all these topics, the statements are
very lucid and explicit.


70 those who may have been apprehensve that
the exclusion of our vessels from the direct trade
TO the British Colonies would cripple our commerce,
it will be satisfactory to learn that such result
has either taken place, or is to be numbered among
the probable consequences of that measure. Not
withstanding that the British Government declines
all further negotiation this subject, therefore, the
predictions Of the factious, andthe fears
to the evils this exclusive policy may inct on US,
gratutous and without foundation. As regards
the other nations of Europe, the views contained in
the Message embrace amity and reciprocal conf
dence.


The abstract view taken Of our finances is most
gratifying. We have reached the lowest point in
the ebb Of our commerce. and the tide of prosperity
is returning upon US. Under the greatest Difficult
ties to which we have been subjected, il is for proud
and grateful recollection, that no interruption has
been made in the progress of the liquidation of ou
public debt. 1t is gradually and steadily diminish
ed, until it does not at this time exceed sixty
millions. Our exports have increased, until the,
have exceeded the amount, of our imports. Ou
Post Office Establishment has contributed this yea
upwards Of one hundred thousand dollars to thu
public revenue, instead Of being, as it formerly was
an annual drain on our Treasury. In short there i
no dark reality for the eye to rest on lin all the rang
of our external and internal economy. Imaginar
vapors may float before the eye of the discontentc


politician, but they are the effect of his own dseas
cd vision, and have no real existence.
From the National Journal.

eomSstcs and the strangers that with them, re-

to his aend like revengeP What have JoA part
ed with your understandings and lost all knowledge
of moral distnction;p' In honor, however, to the

been too late to have saved the state from the stigma
(Which had been so nearly hxed upon its character.
Let this be warning to all future times--and let 1t
be forever remembered that government has never
vet. against its own better knowledge, immolated
victim TO public Glamour and fury, that history has
not stamped upon the sacrifice its just character,
and devoted its aethors to the well deserved exc
craons ofposterity 1t only remains to correct an
error which has gone forth with respect to this mat.
ter, The fatal tree was not plantedthe collin and
grave clothes we're not prepared as 1t has been SAID
merely for the purpose Of extortng confession
from the culprit nor was his pers'sng IN declara
,ions Of his innocence, amid these solemn prepara-
rations, matter that weighed strawwith the 60
vernon. There were deeper and worthier cons,de-
rations then influencing his mind, and which finally
led to the measure of pardoning. ltwas not simply
the circumstance that there was no positive proof
of this mans guilt that he convicted upon pre-.
sumptiye evidence Ii was the whole case. with all
its attendants, which wrought simultaneously on the
public mind an entire regeneration OF sentiment
that found or made the governor its fearless advo.
cate, in despite Of all, the influence which would
have been sure to have pressed down weaker and


meauer spirit, to base surrender of the life OF hu


ina creature to what seemed, but was not then thu


call of public Glamour.

Quick 1faveVing.-By sending express to Bal
timore on Tuesday, after the delivery Of the Presi
dents Message. as to overtake the Eastern mail,
which leaves that city in the steam boat at five
O'Clock in the afternoon we were enabled to furnish
all our Northern and Eastern subscribers with copies
Of the Message, twenty four hours earlier than the
mail would have carried them from this city. The
messenger who performed this service and was also
the bearer of copies for all the Baltimore editors,
left our office door in two horse wagon. at twenty
minutes past twelve O'Clock, and arrived in Baltimore
at half past three Considering that he carried in
his wagon about 5000 copies Of The Message. and
had put two changes Of horses on the road, the jour
ney was performed with surprising quckncss. The
express was furnished by the enterprising mail CON
tractors, Messrs. Stockton K Stokes.
From the National hateAigencer.

We do not propose to offer to our readers any
thing like an exposition of the topics of the Mes
sage. They so perspicuously presented in the
Document itself as to need no eucidation Of
ours We are glad to be able to say. that it appears
to US to be almost faultess State Paper and we
congratulate our readers as well upon the picture
which it exhibits of present national peace and pros
perity, as upon the hopes which it encourages for
the future. The recommendations it contains are
few, because probably other prominent topics than
those embraced in it supposed have been here
tofore presented with sufficient earnesness to Con-
gress. Those recommendations which are added
in the present Message, such as we have always
been ourselves in favour of, and we shall not, in
imitation of some of our associates. now turn our
backs upon them because the President has recon-
mended them.
From the National Intrlligencer.

=


This document WILDE perused with satisfaction and
pride by every true lover Of his country Our foreign
relations maintained in amity; our domestic order&
union unimpared; the country prosperous; revenue
adequate to national wants; and vast terrific
the public credit, and advancing the public improve
ment These, added to the various other particulars
of happiness and security which every mans recol-
lection will aptly furnish him. present picture ol
the most complacent contemplation.


1t is gratifying to find that the only instance in
which our commercial relations remain unadjused or
a fair and kindly footIng has been attended with nt
loss to ourselves. Neither the commerce, the nav
igation, nor the revenue of the United States, has
been diminished by their actual relations with Grea
Britain as to the Colonial Trade.
THE PRESIDENTS MESSAGE.

Governor Giles, of Virginia, took his stand last

The Message of the President seems to have Civ
en- general satisfaction. The Post indeed Of this
city, annoyed by the undoubted fact, that the inter-
ruption Of the direct trade with the West Indies,
has effected very little the commerce, revenue and
navigation Of the United States-still renews its
cayiis against the President for not having humbly
and dutifuy taken advantage of the time ''aowed''
THAT is the language of the Pos by the British gov
ernment, to accept in regard to reciprocal trade,
terms dictated by one Of the parties to it, The
people of the country however will sympathise we
imagine, very little with these regrets of the Eve
ming Post and will rather admire and uphold the de-
csion with which their government refused to accept
as boon what they claimed as right +; and for the
enjoyment of which they were to compensate by
fully equivalent concessions.


The actual condition and prospects of the natio
nal finances, are very gratiiying--the more 50 as
prediction was hazarded by the opposition during
the past summer, nay positive averments were made
that the Treasury would be found unsupplied

full articles.headline: From the National Journal.
full articles.article:
The Message is succnct and satisfactory expo
sition of the relations between the United States and
the other nations OF the world, and of our internal
condition, both as regards our institutions and re-
sources. A considerable portion the Messageis
of necessity, devoted to the history and present
state of our various differences with Great Britain
on the subjects of boundary, intercourse and trade
In relation to all these topics, the statements are
very lucid and explicit.


70 those who may have been apprehensve that
the exclusion of our vessels from the direct trade
TO the British Colonies would cripple our commerce,
it will be satisfactory to learn that such result
has either taken place, or is to be numbered among
the probable consequences of that measure. Not
withstanding that the British Government declines
all further negotiation this subject, therefore, the
predictions Of the factious, andthe fears
to the evils this exclusive policy may inct on US,
gratutous and without foundation. As regards
the other nations of Europe, the views contained in
the Message embrace amity and reciprocal conf
dence.


The abstract view taken Of our finances is most
gratifying. We have reached the lowest point in
the ebb Of our commerce. and the tide of prosperity
is returning upon US. Under the greatest Difficult
ties to which we have been subjected, il is for proud
and grateful recollection, that no interruption has
been made in the progress of the liquidation of ou
public debt. 1t is gradually and steadily diminish
ed, until it does not at this time exceed sixty
millions. Our exports have increased, until the,
have exceeded the amount, of our imports. Ou
Post Office Establishment has contributed this yea
upwards Of one hundred thousand dollars to thu
public revenue, instead Of being, as it formerly was
an annual drain on our Treasury. In short there i
no dark reality for the eye to rest on lin all the rang
of our external and internal economy. Imaginar
vapors may float before the eye of the discontentc


politician, but they are the effect of his own dseas
cd vision, and have no real existence.

eomSstcs and the strangers that with them, re-
norseaessly Offering them all up as great sacr'hce
to his aend like revengeP What have JoA part
ed with your understandings and lost all knowledge
of moral distnction;p' In honor, however, to the
nyope OF Kent-and greatly is tito their honor that
t can be said with truth, that they awoke them
selves, Of their own good sense, to s5uster view OF
their duties--yet still, but for the honor, the inde-
pendence and virtue d the governor, it would have
been too late to have saved the state from the stigma
(Which had been so nearly hxed upon its character.
Let this be warning to all future times--and let 1t
be forever remembered that government has never
vet. against its own better knowledge, immolated
victim TO public Glamour and fury, that history has
not stamped upon the sacrifice its just character,
and devoted its aethors to the well deserved exc
craons ofposterity 1t only remains to correct an
error which has gone forth with respect to this mat.
ter, The fatal tree was not plantedthe collin and
grave clothes we're not prepared as 1t has been SAID
merely for the purpose Of extortng confession
from the culprit nor was his pers'sng IN declara
,ions Of his innocence, amid these solemn prepara-
rations, matter that weighed strawwith the 60
vernon. There were deeper and worthier cons,de-
rations then influencing his mind, and which finally
led to the measure of pardoning. ltwas not simply
the circumstance that there was no positive proof
of this mans guilt that he convicted upon pre-.
sumptiye evidence Ii was the whole case. with all
its attendants, which wrought simultaneously on the
public mind an entire regeneration OF sentiment
that found or made the governor its fearless advo.
cate, in despite Of all, the influence which would
have been sure to have pressed down weaker and


meauer spirit, to base surrender of the life OF hu


ina creature to what seemed, but was not then thu


call of public Glamour.

full articles.article:
Quick 1faveVing.-By sending express to Bal
timore on Tuesday, after the delivery Of the Presi
dents Message. as to overtake the Eastern mail,
which leaves that city in the steam boat at five
O'Clock in the afternoon we were enabled to furnish
all our Northern and Eastern subscribers with copies
Of the Message, twenty four hours earlier than the
mail would have carried them from this city. The
messenger who performed this service and was also
the bearer of copies for all the Baltimore editors,
left our office door in two horse wagon. at twenty
minutes past twelve O'Clock, and arrived in Baltimore
at half past three Considering that he carried in
his wagon about 5000 copies Of The Message. and
had put two changes Of horses on the road, the jour
ney was performed with surprising quckncss. The
express was furnished by the enterprising mail CON
tractors, Messrs. Stockton K Stokes.

full articles.headline: From the National Intrlligencer.
full articles.article:
We do not propose to offer to our readers any
thing like an exposition of the topics of the Mes
sage. They so perspicuously presented in the
Document itself as to need no eucidation Of
ours We are glad to be able to say. that it appears
to US to be almost faultess State Paper and we
congratulate our readers as well upon the picture
which it exhibits of present national peace and pros
perity, as upon the hopes which it encourages for
the future. The recommendations it contains are
few, because probably other prominent topics than
those embraced in it supposed have been here
tofore presented with sufficient earnesness to Con-
gress. Those recommendations which are added
in the present Message, such as we have always
been ourselves in favour of, and we shall not, in
imitation of some of our associates. now turn our
backs upon them because the President has recon-
mended them.

IMITATION.
full articles.article:
Acertain press in Delaware,
which during the last canvass
for the Presidency, indulged
in the use of the most hos
tile expressions against Gen.
Jackson, is now plastering
him with his praises.

full articles.headline: From the Y. S. Gazette.
full articles.article:
We commend the Message of the President to
the careful perusa of readers, satisfied that 1t
will be found among the most satisfactory papers
that nave ever emenated from the executive Of the
nation.

full articles.article:
From the .Ne,p York .qmer'cun.


The Message of the President seems to have Civ
en- general satisfaction. The Post indeed Of this
city, annoyed by the undoubted fact, that the inter-
ruption Of the direct trade with the West Indies,
has effected very little the commerce, revenue and
navigation Of the United States-still renews its
cayiis against the President for not having humbly
and dutifuy taken advantage of the time ''aowed''
THAT is the language of the Pos by the British gov
ernment, to accept in regard to reciprocal trade,
terms dictated by one Of the parties to it, The
people of the country however will sympathise we
imagine, very little with these regrets of the Eve
ming Post and will rather admire and uphold the de-
csion with which their government refused to accept
as boon what they claimed as right +; and for the
enjoyment of which they were to compensate by
fully equivalent concessions.


The actual condition and prospects of the natio
nal finances, are very gratiiying--the more 50 as
prediction was hazarded by the opposition during
the past summer, nay positive averments were made
that the Treasury would be found unsupplied

full articles.headline: From The National Gazette.
full articles.article:
Every reader (of the Message) must acknowl.
edge it to be very able and satisfactory exposition
Of the circumstances and interests of the country

and we believe that there are few who will not feel
it as demonstration, throughout, Of the eminent
fitness Of its author for the post which he occupies

Such is the difference of
tone which has taken place
within a few months, in ,hs.,
paper. ~
